page.title: 17FARMING, RUGELEY
page.content: The farm land to the northeast of Rugeley occupies the flood plain of the River Trent, the southwest-facing valley side and the low ridge rising 50 metres above the Trent separating it from the small valley of the River Blythe. Fields adjacent to the river are prone to waterlogging rather than flooding and are used for grazing cattle. Over the rest of the area, the soil is rich and given over to mixed farming. This is mainly improved grassland, cereals, oilseed rape and root vegetables - usually potatoes. The grazing is usually on the steeper slopes or the flat land on the valley floor. Most grazing is for cattle, the remainder being for sheep. There are about 20 farms in the survey block ranging in size from 40 to over 200 acres in size. There is one intensive pig farm in the area.
